values.description: This probably seems like a minor change, but it's a blocker for some `ign-physics` work that I'm doing right now, because without this operator being const-correct, I would have to violate const-correctness for a whole slew of functions that depend on this operator.
values.title: Fixing const-correctness for operator* of Pose3

summary.raw: This probably seems like a minor change, but it's a blocker for some `ign-physics` work that I'm doing right now, because without this operator being const-correct, I would have to violate const-correctness for a whole slew of functions that depend on this operator.

values.description:
As a consequence of the following PR's:

* https://bitbucket.org/osrf/release-tools/pull-requests/463/proposal-updating-to-visual-studio-2017
* #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/pull-requests/204/proposal-updating-to-visual-studio-2017

the windows jenkins builds are broken for branches older than default:

* https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_math-ci-pr_any-windows7-amd64/337

This fixes the Windows CI. ~~Are there any tutorials that this will break?~~ I've tested the following tutorial ~~and it still works~~ ~~and it configures but doesn't give the same install location~~ and I've added a check for a blank value of `WORKSPACE_INSTALL_DIR` in 0bb06fce279f that uses the legacy install location to keep the tutorial functioning:

* http://gazebosim.org/tutorials?tut=install_on_windows&cat=install#Installation

I think this should be safe to merge. We may want to update the tutorial for new versions of ignition math or just keep this legacy behavior when the variable is unset.
values.title: backport updated configure.bat to ign-math3

summary.raw:
As a consequence of the following PR's:

* https://bitbucket.org/osrf/release-tools/pull-requests/463/proposal-updating-to-visual-studio-2017
* #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/pull-requests/204/proposal-updating-to-visual-studio-2017

the windows jenkins builds are broken for branches older than default:

* https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_math-ci-pr_any-windows7-amd64/337

This fixes the Windows CI. ~~Are there any tutorials that this will break?~~ I've tested the following tutorial ~~and it still works~~ ~~and it configures but doesn't give the same install location~~ and I've added a check for a blank value of `WORKSPACE_INSTALL_DIR` in 0bb06fce279f that uses the legacy install location to keep the tutorial functioning:

* http://gazebosim.org/tutorials?tut=install_on_windows&cat=install#Installation

I think this should be safe to merge. We may want to update the tutorial for new versions of ignition math or just keep this legacy behavior when the variable is unset.
summary.html:
As a consequence of the following PR's:

  • https://bitbucket.org/osrf/release-tools/pull-requests/463/proposal-updating-to-visual-studio-2017
  • #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/pull-requests/204/proposal-updating-to-visual-studio-2017

the windows jenkins builds are broken for branches older than default:

  • https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_math-ci-pr_any-windows7-amd64/337

This fixes the Windows CI. Are there any tutorials that this will break? I've tested the following tutorial and it still works and it configures but doesn't give the same install location and I've added a check for a blank value of WORKSPACE_INSTALL_DIR in 0bb06fce279f that uses the legacy install location to keep the tutorial functioning:

  • http://gazebosim.org/tutorials?tut=install_on_windows&cat=install#Installation

I think this should be safe to merge. We may want to update the tutorial for new versions of ignition math or just keep this legacy behavior when the variable is unset.

values.description:
(same as pull request #206)

The [xenial build](https://build.osrfoundation.org//job/ignition_math-ci-pr_any-xenial-amd64/77) had some cppcheck warnings, so I added some cppcheck fixes in fe28409  and 83d9dec and a missing script used by code_check.sh in 065073d, so the [xenial build is now fixed](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_math-ci-pr_any-xenial-amd64/81/).

The [windows build](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_math-ci-pr_any-windows7-amd64/340/warningsResult/) has a compiler warning that doesn't show up on the default branch, even though the relevant code hasn't changed. Maybe we are using different compiler flags?
values.title: backport updated configure.bat to ign-math2

summary.raw:
(same as pull request #206)

The [xenial build](https://build.osrfoundation.org//job/ignition_math-ci-pr_any-xenial-amd64/77) had some cppcheck warnings, so I added some cppcheck fixes in fe28409  and 83d9dec and a missing script used by code_check.sh in 065073d, so the [xenial build is now fixed](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_math-ci-pr_any-xenial-amd64/81/).

The [windows build](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_math-ci-pr_any-windows7-amd64/340/warningsResult/) has a compiler warning that doesn't show up on the default branch, even though the relevant code hasn't changed. Maybe we are using different compiler flags?
summary.html:
(same as pull request #206)

The xenial build had some cppcheck warnings, so I added some cppcheck fixes in fe28409 and 83d9dec and a missing script used by code_check.sh in 065073d, so the xenial build is now fixed.

The windows build has a compiler warning that doesn't show up on the default branch, even though the relevant code hasn't changed. Maybe we are using different compiler flags?

values.description:
I propose we make a ~~3.2.1~~ 3.3.0 release which includes the changes merged since the 3.2.0 release.

* Merged `ign-math2` into `ign-math3`
* Updated the changelog based on [merged pull requests](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/branches/compare/ign-math3%0Dignition-math3_3.2.0#pull-requests)
* Set the tentative release date for 2 days from now

~~The reason for only bumping the patch version is that there are mainly warning fixes and bug fixes. The changes on pull request #181 could be considered a "feature" though, so I could be convinced to release 3.3.0.~~ 3.3.0 it is, see comments
values.title: 3.3.0 release

summary.raw:
I propose we make a ~~3.2.1~~ 3.3.0 release which includes the changes merged since the 3.2.0 release.

* Merged `ign-math2` into `ign-math3`
* Updated the changelog based on [merged pull requests](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/branches/compare/ign-math3%0Dignition-math3_3.2.0#pull-requests)
* Set the tentative release date for 2 days from now

~~The reason for only bumping the patch version is that there are mainly warning fixes and bug fixes. The changes on pull request #181 could be considered a "feature" though, so I could be convinced to release 3.3.0.~~ 3.3.0 it is, see comments
summary.html:
I propose we make a 3.2.1 3.3.0 release which includes the changes merged since the 3.2.0 release.

  • Merged ign-math2 into ign-math3
  • Updated the changelog based on merged pull requests
  • Set the tentative release date for 2 days from now

The reason for only bumping the patch version is that there are mainly warning fixes and bug fixes. The changes on pull request #181 could be considered a "feature" though, so I could be convinced to release 3.3.0. 3.3.0 it is, see comments

values.description:
Follow up from today's meeting, this PR adds versioned inlined namespaces. Major versions of ignition math can be linked into the same executable because the symbol names between two major versions no longer overlap.


More info on past PRs

* pull request #179
* pull request #202
values.title: Versioned inline namespaces

values.description:
We have some custom parsing code in the `parseInt` and `parseFloat` functions in Helpers.hh. This migrates to using `std::stoi` and `std::stod` to remove over 30 lines of code.

The STL functions have slightly different behavior when parsing alphanumeric strings that start with a valid number, so I've updated the test and Migration guide. This behavior change doesn't strike me as a huge problem.
values.title: Use std::stoi and std::stod in math::parse* functions to reduce code (#50)

summary.raw:
We have some custom parsing code in the `parseInt` and `parseFloat` functions in Helpers.hh. This migrates to using `std::stoi` and `std::stod` to remove over 30 lines of code.

The STL functions have slightly different behavior when parsing alphanumeric strings that start with a valid number, so I've updated the test and Migration guide. This behavior change doesn't strike me as a huge problem.
summary.html:
We have some custom parsing code in the parseInt and parseFloat functions in Helpers.hh. This migrates to using std::stoi and std::stod to remove over 30 lines of code.

The STL functions have slightly different behavior when parsing alphanumeric strings that start with a valid number, so I've updated the test and Migration guide. This behavior change doesn't strike me as a huge problem.

values.description:
Requires [this PR](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-cmake/pull-requests/31/filter-inline-namespaces/diff).

A lot of magic happens in doxygen. The best solution I could find to remove inline namespaces to to filter them using sed. However, the filter has to include the open curly bracket, otherwise the class is omitted from doxygen.
values.title: Fix inline namespace and doxygen

summary.raw:
Requires [this PR](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-cmake/pull-requests/31/filter-inline-namespaces/diff).

A lot of magic happens in doxygen. The best solution I could find to remove inline namespaces to to filter them using sed. However, the filter has to include the open curly bracket, otherwise the class is omitted from doxygen.
summary.html:
Requires this PR.

A lot of magic happens in doxygen. The best solution I could find to remove inline namespaces to to filter them using sed. However, the filter has to include the open curly bracket, otherwise the class is omitted from doxygen.

values.description:
There are two [gcc7 implicit-fallthrough= warnings on artful](https://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ignition_math-ci-ign-math4-artful-amd64/1/warnings22Result/). Based on the advice in [this redhat article](https://developers.redhat.com/blog/2017/03/10/wimplicit-fallthrough-in-gcc-7/), I've added comments where switch statement cases are intended to fallthough, which is enough to quiet gcc7.

There are already comments a few lines above this indicating that the lack of a `break;` statement is intentional, but the new comments are parseable by gcc7.
values.title: Fix gcc7 compiler warnings on artful

summary.raw:
There are two [gcc7 implicit-fallthrough= warnings on artful](https://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ignition_math-ci-ign-math4-artful-amd64/1/warnings22Result/). Based on the advice in [this redhat article](https://developers.redhat.com/blog/2017/03/10/wimplicit-fallthrough-in-gcc-7/), I've added comments where switch statement cases are intended to fallthough, which is enough to quiet gcc7.

There are already comments a few lines above this indicating that the lack of a `break;` statement is intentional, but the new comments are parseable by gcc7.
summary.html:
There are two gcc7 implicit-fallthrough= warnings on artful. Based on the advice in this redhat article, I've added comments where switch statement cases are intended to fallthough, which is enough to quiet gcc7.

There are already comments a few lines above this indicating that the lack of a break; statement is intentional, but the new comments are parseable by gcc7.

values.description:
There are some [cppcheck complaints on artful](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_math-ci-default-artful-amd64/1/cppcheckResult/). This fixes them:

* remove cppcheck defines, since that was messing up noExplicitConstructor suppressions

* suppress 'class IGNITION_MATH_VISIBLE PID {' is not handled.' error (caused by class name `PID` in all-caps I think)

* add copy constructor and test to Plane class

* suppress knownConditionTrueFalse cppcheck complaints in Angle_TEST

* test with cppcheck xml version 2 (version 1 is deprecated)

:blue_circle:  https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_math-ci-pr_any-artful-amd64/1/
values.title: Add Plane copy constructor and fix cppcheck on artful

* suppress 'class IGNITION_MATH_VISIBLE PID {' is not handled.' error (caused by class name `PID` in all-caps I think)

summary.html:
There are some cppcheck complaints on artful. This fixes them:

  • remove cppcheck defines, since that was messing up noExplicitConstructor suppressions

  • suppress 'class IGNITION_MATH_VISIBLE PID {' is not handled.' error (caused by class name PID in all-caps I think)

  • add copy constructor and test to Plane class

  • suppress knownConditionTrueFalse cppcheck complaints in Angle_TEST

  • test with cppcheck xml version 2 (version 1 is deprecated)

values.description:
This should fix the problem [reported](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/pull-requests/232/bug-in-pairing-function-insde-helperscc/diff#comment-59266386) about the problem when compiling ign-math4 in Ubuntu Artful. I think that the issue is [well explained](https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1321986) by the maintainer of GCC:

```plaintext
The error is correct.  Hexadecimal floats are part of C99, C11 and the upcoming C++17 standards, while for C89, C++11 and C++14 they are just extensions.
So, you need -std=gnu89, -std=gnu++11 or -std=gnu++14 instead of -std=c89, -std=c++11 or -std=c++14 to enable them (or -std=c99, -std=c11, -std=c++17).
```

In summary as I understand: it was working on previous versions of G\+\+ \(Xenial has 5.x series\) but the support is only native when using c\+\+17 standard.

The PR looks for the C\+\+17 support \(literal 201703L\) and also add enough precession to the decimal expression so it can fix the orginal [debian bug](https://bugs.debian.org/cgi-bin/bugreport.cgi?bug=888220#10).
values.title: Ign math4 exponents standard version

summary.raw:
This should fix the problem [reported](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/pull-requests/232/bug-in-pairing-function-insde-helperscc/diff#comment-59266386) about the problem when compiling ign-math4 in Ubuntu Artful. I think that the issue is [well explained](https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1321986) by the maintainer of GCC:

```plaintext
The error is correct.  Hexadecimal floats are part of C99, C11 and the upcoming C++17 standards, while for C89, C++11 and C++14 they are just extensions.
So, you need -std=gnu89, -std=gnu++11 or -std=gnu++14 instead of -std=c89, -std=c++11 or -std=c++14 to enable them (or -std=c99, -std=c11, -std=c++17).
```

In summary as I understand: it was working on previous versions of G\+\+ \(Xenial has 5.x series\) but the support is only native when using c\+\+17 standard.

The PR looks for the C\+\+17 support \(literal 201703L\) and also add enough precession to the decimal expression so it can fix the orginal [debian bug](https://bugs.debian.org/cgi-bin/bugreport.cgi?bug=888220#10).
summary.html:
This should fix the problem reported about the problem when compiling ign-math4 in Ubuntu Artful. I think that the issue is well explained by the maintainer of GCC:

The error is correct.  Hexadecimal floats are part of C99, C11 and the upcoming C++17 standards, while for C89, C++11 and C++14 they are just extensions.
So, you need -std=gnu89, -std=gnu++11 or -std=gnu++14 instead of -std=c89, -std=c++11 or -std=c++14 to enable them (or -std=c99, -std=c11, -std=c++17).

In summary as I understand: it was working on previous versions of G++ (Xenial has 5.x series) but the support is only native when using c++17 standard.

The PR looks for the C++17 support (literal 201703L) and also add enough precession to the decimal expression so it can fix the orginal debian bug.

values.title: Adding material density

summary.html:
Mostly a copy of ignition::common::MaterialDensity. The version in common used common's EnumIface class, which I didn't want to port over.

Instead, this version of MaterialDensity has added a Material class, and moved the material type enum outside of the MaterialDensity class.

The API is now a bit easier to use:

In Common

MaterialDensity::Type material;
 double density;
 std::tie(material, density) = MaterialDensity::Nearest(19300.0);
std::cout << "Mat Type[" << material << "] Density[" << density << "]\n";

In Math:

Material mat = MaterialDensity::Nearest(19300.0);
std::cout << "Mat Type[" << mat.type << "] Density[" << mat.density << "]\n";

values.description:
This started as a move of ignition common's MaterialDensity class, but has since transformed into a rewrite.

The major difference is that MaterialDensity has become a more generic Material class. This will let us add other properties, such as coefficient of friction, to materials in the future.

The process of adding new built-in materials is a bit more straightforward now. You'll have to add an entry to the enum in `include/ignition/math/MaterialTypes.hh` and a corresponding entry in `src/MaterialTypes.hh`. I could rename the file `src/MaterialTypes.hh` to something different, but it felt convenient to have them match.

I also tweaked cpplint.py to let the `&&` move notation pass.
values.title: Material density

summary.raw:
This started as a move of ignition common's MaterialDensity class, but has since transformed into a rewrite.

The major difference is that MaterialDensity has become a more generic Material class. This will let us add other properties, such as coefficient of friction, to materials in the future.

The process of adding new built-in materials is a bit more straightforward now. You'll have to add an entry to the enum in `include/ignition/math/MaterialTypes.hh` and a corresponding entry in `src/MaterialTypes.hh`. I could rename the file `src/MaterialTypes.hh` to something different, but it felt convenient to have them match.

I also tweaked cpplint.py to let the `&&` move notation pass.
summary.html:
This started as a move of ignition common's MaterialDensity class, but has since transformed into a rewrite.

The major difference is that MaterialDensity has become a more generic Material class. This will let us add other properties, such as coefficient of friction, to materials in the future.

The process of adding new built-in materials is a bit more straightforward now. You'll have to add an entry to the enum in include/ignition/math/MaterialTypes.hh and a corresponding entry in src/MaterialTypes.hh. I could rename the file src/MaterialTypes.hh to something different, but it felt convenient to have them match.

I also tweaked cpplint.py to let the && move notation pass.

values.description:
There is a discrepancy between how ign-math and Drake compute valid moments.
Ign-math was use the `>` comparison without an epsilon, and Drake is using `>=` with an epsilon.

** Real-life example **

A solid cylinder with length = 1.0 m, radius = 0.001 m, and mass = 1kg would have the following inertia:

* ixx = 0.08333
* iyy = 0.08333
* izz = 5e-7

Drake allows setting `izz` to zero.  

In many of our models we have very small values for some inertia values. My current understanding is that ign-math's original check is more correct (i.e. ixx, iyy, izz can never be zero in reality) but the implementation also more restrictive. 

In summary, this PR is really a proposal about supporting non-realistic but plausible inertia values. Reviewers should also take into consideration that machine encoding of float values has limited precision, which is handled more elegantly with the PR.
values.title: Updated the MassMatrix3::ValidMoments to use an epsilon and >=

summary.raw:
There is a discrepancy between how ign-math and Drake compute valid moments.
Ign-math was use the `>` comparison without an epsilon, and Drake is using `>=` with an epsilon.

** Real-life example **

A solid cylinder with length = 1.0 m, radius = 0.001 m, and mass = 1kg would have the following inertia:

* ixx = 0.08333
* iyy = 0.08333
* izz = 5e-7

Drake allows setting `izz` to zero.  

In many of our models we have very small values for some inertia values. My current understanding is that ign-math's original check is more correct (i.e. ixx, iyy, izz can never be zero in reality) but the implementation also more restrictive. 

In summary, this PR is really a proposal about supporting non-realistic but plausible inertia values. Reviewers should also take into consideration that machine encoding of float values has limited precision, which is handled more elegantly with the PR.
summary.html:
There is a discrepancy between how ign-math and Drake compute valid moments. Ign-math was use the > comparison without an epsilon, and Drake is using >= with an epsilon.

Real-life example

A solid cylinder with length = 1.0 m, radius = 0.001 m, and mass = 1kg would have the following inertia:

  • ixx = 0.08333
  • iyy = 0.08333
  • izz = 5e-7

Drake allows setting izz to zero.

In many of our models we have very small values for some inertia values. My current understanding is that ign-math's original check is more correct (i.e. ixx, iyy, izz can never be zero in reality) but the implementation also more restrictive.

In summary, this PR is really a proposal about supporting non-realistic but plausible inertia values. Reviewers should also take into consideration that machine encoding of float values has limited precision, which is handled more elegantly with the PR.
